Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: High Performance Structural Composites with Cellulosic Nanoparticles
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project seeks to commercialize high-strength thermoplastic composites reinforced with cellulosic nanoparticles (CNs) as a replacement for heavier glass‐reinforced composite materials for structural automotive components. The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to create sustainable, high‐performance nanocomposites. Expected weight savings is between 13 and 20% per component. Corporate Average Fuel Economy (CAFE) regulations require significant increases in fuel economy for vehicles, which has led carmakers to look for innovative ways to shed vehicle weight. It has been shown that for every 10% in weight savings, vehicle fuel consumption is reduced by 7%. The target application is to replace heavy glass reinforcement in polymeric composites with CNCs for car parts, providing lighter weight vehicles with increased fuel efficiency. On‐going research into CN materials has resulted in significant reductions in cost (with more reductions expected), making CNs an increasingly attractive functional natural nanofiller, the processing of which will provide jobs in both the manufacturing and the technology sector. Successful implementation of CNs into composites could not only lighten vehicles and reduce environmental impact, but also transform a waste stream into value-added materials, reducing the amount of waste produced by these industries.

During the SBIR Phase I period, the company showed that lighter thermoplastic composites reinforced with cellulosic nanoparticles could meet the tensile strength values of glass-reinforced composites with much higher loadings, thereby saving part weight. The Phase II grant will allow the company to scale up the manufacturing processes necessary to produce these lighter, more sustainable composites for the automotive industry. Furthermore, the company will improve performance of these materials in order to attain performance parity with higher‐loaded glass‐reinforced parts and potentially to compete with ultra‐high performance materials such as carbon fiber composites and metals. This technology will be produced using efficient and economical manufacturing processes, allowing this to become a true drop‐in technology for automotive part-makers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit

As the part of the NSF phase II project, Essentium has discovered, developed, proven at pilot-scale, three tangible items. Firstly, a nano-micro composite was developed by Essentium that contains nanocellulose (NC) and other fillers in a polypropylene matrix. Mechanical property improvements were possible due to development of a reactive twin-screw extrusion process. Commercial customer interest developed as a result of this work. Essentium ArborX™, tradename for our novel composites, meets requirements for incumbent glass fiber filled polypropylene composite mechanical property specifications while achieving weight savings of 4.5% and 7% respectively when compared to 20% and 30% glass filled composites. Second, the developed process was engineered to produce filament reinforced with nanocellulose in polymer matrices like poly (lactic acid) (PLA) and poly (amides) (PA) for additive manufacturing (AM) purposes. Achieving the required diameter, ovality and filler dispersion consistency were key drivers for successful filament production since fillers make it hard to achieve the above-mentioned parameters. Third, a new process to add hydrophobic functionality to nanocellulose surfaces was developed which will reduce NC particle agglomeration upon drying while improving dispersibility upon further processing. This single step process can be added to existing nanocellulose manufacturing lines to achieve hydrophobic nanocellulose that is more compatible for reinforcing plastic matrices.

Broader impact

The production of nanocellulose and microcellulose raw inputs provides broad opportunities to repurpose dormant paper- and pulp-production facilities, invigorating an entire supply chain while transforming biological wastes into engineered materials. Further, the usage of these inputs in plastic composites for automotive applications provides lightweighting opportunities which reduce fuel consumption in America’s vehicles.  Essentium’s ArborX™ nanocellulose based composite will rightly support these goals. Further, incorporating nanocellulose provides a green reinforcement material which has a low energy cost to produce compared to traditional filler materials like carbon fibers, glass fibers and others. Also, a single step process which modifies the nanocellulose particle surface to be more hydrophobic will result in many more viable applications for nanocellulose in the plastics industry. Additionally, the usage of NC input materials in Additive Manufacturing provides reshoring and local-for-local manufacturing opportunities in the US. Simply put, AM provides the ability for anyone from hobbyists to large corporations to print many more types of structures than traditional methods, reducing lead times and minimizing material costs. The production of new, environmentally friendly composite plastic products resultant from this project provided solutions for traditional manufacturing methods such as injection molding, and new manufacturing methods such as AM.


Last Modified: 12/07/2018
Modified by: Elisa Teipel
